CARDINAL . On DATE the court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . It imposed a fine on ORG equivalent to CARDINAL days’ imprisonment . The court considered that the use of an “ undercover ” agent or even an “ agent provocateur ” did not appear to be prohibited under domestic legislation , provided that the sacrifice of the accused ’s individual freedom was justified by the values that were being upheld . As the applicant had initially been approached by F.O. the conduct of the ORG officers had not been “ decisive ” in the commission of the offence . The court explained that it had reached its verdict on the basis of the statements of the witness , F.O. , the co - defendant , GPE , the applicant himself and , “ mainly ” , of the QUANTITY police officers .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against that decision to ORG . He complained of a breach of the right to a fair hearing and relied , inter alia , on LAW .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed his appeal and upheld all the provisions of the judgment appealed against , holding that :

“ In the instant case it is indisputable that the ORG officers ... were extremely pressing until they were introduced to PERSON . It was , however , only natural that that should have been the course adopted . The police officers knew that PERSON was a drug user and sought to unmask the person responsible for supplying him with drugs . No hashish being available , they tried to obtain heroin and met PERSON , who agreed to their false proposals because he aimed to make a profit out of the deal , thereby exploiting one of the major scourges of our time ...
The PSP officers’ perseverance was thus rewarded since they arrested the applicant in possession of what was already a considerable quantity of the drug .

Moreover , as officers in the Public Security Police based at the NORP police station , the policemen ... were acting as criminal investigators ( LAW ) under the powers vested in them by statute enabling them , without referring to higher authority , to obtain information about offences , identify offenders and take any steps that were necessary and urgent to preserve evidence ( LAW ) .

Police officers ... act in criminal proceedings as officers of the court , but that does not prevent them taking , in special statutorily defined circumstances , procedural steps in the exercise of their own undelegated powers .
As the public prosecutor said in his submissions , the ORG officers acted within the law and their conduct did not render the evidence obtained inadmissible .
In these circumstances , PERSON appeal is wholly unfounded .
In the light of these considerations ORG dismisses the appeal and upholds all the provisions of the judgment appealed against . ”

CARDINAL . Legal writers in GPE ( and in other NORP countries ) draw a distinction , under the generic term of “ infiltrators ” , between an “ undercover agent ” and an “ agent provocateur ” . The former is someone who confines himself to gathering information , whereas the latter is someone who actually incites people to commit a criminal offence .
